member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Truss.Binding
member.summary: Connects a target property to a single source property using simple path-formatted strings to resolve the bound properties on both the target and source objects.

remarks.para: Instances of the Binding class can be used to connect together two properties. The properties are specified via strings, so there is no compile-time check to ensure that the property actually exists. If the types of the target and source objects are known, it is recommended that a be used rather than a Binding.

The syntax for specifying a property is similar to that of C#. For example, a target path of "PropertyName" will attempt to resolve a property called "PropertyName" on the target object. A target path of "Parent.Child" will attempt first to resolve a property called "Parent" on the target object, and then a property called "Child" on the value of the "Parent" property.

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Truss.MultiBinding
member.summary: Connects a target property to multiple source properties using a simple path-formatted string to resolve the bound property on the target object.

remarks.para: Instances of the MultiBinding class can be used to connect together multiple source properties to a single target property. The target property is specified via a string, so there is no compile-time check to ensure that the property actually exists. If the type of the target is known at compile-time, it is recommended that a be used rather than a MultiBinding.

The bindings comprising the sources for the MultiBinding must be added to the collection prior to activation. Only s are supported, and target information for those bindings must be absent. Only the source information should be provided.
A MultiBinding always requires a converter be set via the property before it can be activated.

The syntax for specifying a property is similar to that of C#. For example, a target path of "PropertyName" will attempt to resolve a property called "PropertyName" on the target object. A target path of "Parent.Child" will attempt first to resolve a property called "Parent" on the target object, and then a property called "Child" on the value of the "Parent" property.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how a MultiBinding can be used to connect the DeliveryAddress property of a Mail instance to multiple address-related properties in a Customer instance using the fluent interface:
var bindingManager = new BindingManager(); bindingManager.MultiBind(mail, "DeliveryAddress) .WithConverter(new AddressConverter()) .To(customer, x => x.Address.Line1) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.Line2) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.Line3) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.PostCode) .Activate();

remarks.para: This class extends for bindings that have multiple sources. Each source is represented as an instance of inside the collection. Bindings added to this collection must have only their source information set, as the target is implicitly the MultiSourceBinding.

Since there is no sensible default way to convert multiple sources into a single target and vice versa, every MultiSourceBinding requires a converter. member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Truss.TypedMultiBinding`1
member.summary: Connects a target property to multiple source properties using a lambda expression to resolve the target property.

remarks.para: Instances of the TypedMultiBinding class can be used to connect together multiple source properties to a single target property. The target property is specified via a lambda expression, so it is checked at compile-time. Because of this, it is recommended that a TypedMultiBindingbe used in preference to a wherever possible.

The bindings comprising the sources for the TypedMultiBinding must be added to the collection prior to activation. Only s are supported, and target information for those bindings must be absent. Only the source information should be provided.
A TypedMultiBinding always requires a converter be set via the property before it can be activated.

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how a TypedMultiBinding can be used to connect the DeliveryAddress property of a Mail instance to multiple address-related properties in a Customer instance using the fluent interface:
var bindingManager = new BindingManager(); bindingManager.MultiBind(mail, x => x.DeliveryAddress) .WithConverter(new AddressConverter()) .To(customer, x => x.Address.Line1) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.Line2) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.Line3) .AndTo(customer, x => x.Address.PostCode) .Activate();
member.typeparam: The type of the target object.
